column4: root is a different group and has a *very* different purpose than wheel
group root is meant for root to be able to have a umask of 002, allowing group projects, but preventing any user other than root from writing to roots files
what is the drawback for using the group wheel like the group root?
root must not have a umask of 00*, making group projects harder
on a single user machine, or even a family machine, it doesn't matter, but it does on machines like shell.sourceforge.net
I'm note quite sure what you mean with group projects. All members of the group root have root access anyway, so I don't understand the difference..
lets say you have a website in /var/www/grproj.example.net user: rmx group: grproj
you want any user in group grproj to be able to read/write to /var/www/grproj.example.net
so far I understood, but whats the problem with the root group now?
if root wants to change something in /var/www/grproj.example.net, s/he has to have a umask of 002 to keep perms the same
if root has a umask of 002, any user of group root can edit his/her files

this seems to me only a problem when working a lot as root, which is deprecated anyways. I think I see your point, but not the practical relevance when using root only for doing small administrative jobs
you're right, this applies more to common users than root
but thanks for your explanation. next time I setup a server like shell.sf.net I'll remember that. :)
